Tyml Specification 0.9 - Draft

Introduction

Tyml is a text based and typed markup and data description language that is meant to be an alternative to XML, JSON and YAML. Tyml is the abbreviation of Typed markup language.

Because Tyml is typed, every object must specify a global type for which it describes an instance. Tyml documents can be validated and processed easily by using the associated type information. This makes tools possible that can provide domain specific assistance like autocompletion or graphical user interfaces for editing Tyml documents.
The concept of namespaces that is inspired by xml prevents type and attribute naming collisions, so that each tyml object can be extended by custom attributes in a custom namespace without neccessary influencing the processing of the document. Thus, each tyml document can be extended at will.

Tyml supports the description of objects, lists, strings and primitives. Primitives are strings that have a user defined meaning like numbers or booleans. Moreover, tyml supports embedding objects mixed with arbitrary text into a markup string.

This makes tyml suitable to describe complex configurations and extensive markup documents, while still being appropriate to store and transmit simple data due to its compact notation.

Terminology

The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

Goal of this Specification

This specification defines the formal language of Tyml, the logical tree of well-formed Tyml documents and how programs can process Tyml documents.

Tyml Programs

Tyml addresses all programs that want to write or read any kind of structured data.

Definition: Tyml Processor
Any program that processes Tyml Documents, whether it is reading or writing, is called Tyml Processor.

Definition: Tyml Text Editor
Any program that provides a textual editor for editing tyml documents by modifying characters, is called Tyml Text Editor.

Logical Structure

Notation

In the following, the Expressive Grammar Language (EGL) 1.0 is used to describe Productions that define various Symbols. The underlying Alphabet consists of exactly all Unicode Printable Characters. If a String matches a given Symbol, Parse Trees are yielded as described by the EGL specification. These Parse Trees describe all possible logical structures of the String that matched the given Symbol.

When this specification names a certain symbol, it often refers to the corresponding nodes of the parse trees.

The text of an optional child node is the text of the child node if it exists, otherwise it is the Empty String.

Null refers to a special value that is different from every other value.

Identifiers

Identifiers have the following form:

Identifier ::= IdentifierStartChar IdentifierContChar* IdentifierStartChar ::= '_' | unicode:ID_Start IdentifierContChar ::= '_' | '.' | '-' | unicode:ID_Continue

unicode:ID_Start and unicode:ID_Continue refer to the corresponding Unicode properties.

Whitespaces and Comments

Whitespace characters are described as following:

SingleLineWSChar ::= #x09 | #x20 LineBreak ::= #x0D #x0A | #x0D | #x0A WS ::= SingleLineWSChar | LineBreak

Comments have the following structure:

Comment ::= '{-' Delimiter '-' AnyText '-' Delimiter '-}' Delimiter ::= unicode:ID_Continue* AnyText ::= .*

Constraint: Syntactical Correctness
The text of both Delimiter children of a Comment MUST match and is called the Delimiter of the Comment. The text of AnyText children MUST NOT contain - followed by the Delimiter and then by -}.

Trivias are a sequence of whitespaces or comments:

Trivias ::= (WS | Comment)+

Namespace System

Namespaces are used to avoid naming collisions. Since namespaces can become quite long, prefixes are used to shorten them:

Namespace ::= (Identifier '/')* Identifier Prefix ::= Identifier?

Such namespace prefixes can be defined by PrefixDefs nodes in the following way:

PrefixDef ::= '!ns' '/' Prefix ':' Trivias? '<' Namespace '>'

Property: PrefixDef → Prefix
The prefix defined by a PrefixDef is the text of the Prefix child.

Property: PrefixDef → Namespace
The namespace specified by a PrefixDef is the text of its Namespace child.

Namespaces SHOULD start with a domain name owned by the author to prevent naming collisions.

Each node of a Parse Tree resolves a prefix to either a namespace or to Null. If not defined otherwise, a node resolves a prefix to Null if it does not have a parent. If it has a parent, the prefix is resolved to the value the parent resolves the prefix to.

However, if the node has a PrefixDef child that defines the prefix, the prefix is resolved to the namespace the PrefixDef child specifies.

Constraint: Well-formedness
When removing a PrefixDef node from its Parse Tree, its former parent must resolve the prefix defined by the PrefixDef to Null.

Prefixes are used for type names:

LocalTypeName ::= Identifier TypeName ::= (Prefix '/')? LocalTypeName QualifiedTypeName ::= Namespace '#' LocalTypeName

A TypeName consists of a prefix that is the text of the optional Prefix child and a local type name that is the text of the LocalTypeName child.

Constraint: Well-formedness
A TypeName MUST NOT resolve its prefix to Null.

Property: TypeName → Qualified Type Name
A TypeName node resolves to a QualifiedTypeName. It consists of the namespace to which the node resolves the prefix and of the local type name.

Example: Type Name resolution

{t/MyTypeName !ns/t:<tyml.org/example>} {MyTypeName !ns/:<tyml.org/example>}

Both type names resolve to the qualified type name tyml.org/example#MyTypeName.

Tyml Documents

Definition: Tyml Document
A String is called a Tyml Document iff it matches the production RecognizedAsTymlDocument.

RecognizedAsTymlDocument ::= '{!tyml' AnyText

Definition: Syntactically Correct
A Tyml Document is called Syntactically Correct iff it matches the production Document and there is at least one Parse Tree that fulfills all Syntactical Correctness constraints given in this specification.

Definition: Logical Tree
The syntactical correctness constraints ensure that Syntactically Correct Tyml Documents have exactly one Parse Tree. This tree is called the Logical Tree of the Tyml Document.

Definition: Well-formed
A Syntactically Correct Tyml Document is called Well-formed iff its Logical Tree fulfills all Well-formedness constraints given in this specification.

Document ::= Header (Trivias? Object)* Trivias?

The document header is used for recognizing a tyml document including its version and for specifying global namespace prefixes. Document nodes use the Header child for resolving prefixes. The header is defined as follows:

Header ::= '{!tyml 0.9' (Trivias PrefixDef)* (Trivias AliasDef)* (Trivias HeaderAttr)* Trivias? '}'

Later versions of Tyml will not change the RecognizedAsTymlDocument production but will increase the header's version number. For future Tyml 1.0 documents however, the version will be optional and a non-digit char will follow instead.

Alias definitions can be used to shorten object types. They are defined as follows:

AliasDef ::= '!alias/#' AliasName ':' Trivias? '<' TypeName '>' AliasName ::= Identifier

An AliasDef defines an alias name and assigns it the qualified type name of its TypeName child.

Constraint: Well-formedness
Different AliasDefs MUST define different alias names.

Header attributes are defined as following:

HeaderAttr ::= HeaderAttrName ':' Trivias? AttributeValue HeaderAttrName ::= Identifier AttributeValue ::= Expression

Valid header attributes are defined in type system section.

Example: Well-formed Tyml Document

{!tyml 0.9 !ns/:<tyml.org/example> !alias/#Root:<ApplicationRoot> } {#Root}

Expressions

Expressions can either be literals or containers for other Expressions:

Expression ::= Literal | Container Literal ::= Primitive | String Container ::= Object | Array

Property: Literal → Value
Literals represent an unicode string called Value.

Primitives

Primitives represent atomic values like booleans or numbers:

Primitive ::= PrimitiveChar+ PrimitiveChar ::= IdentifierContChar | [+*=|~!?,;/\"'()^&@%$#]

Property: Primitive → Value
The Value of a Primitive is its Text.

Strings

There are two different possibilities to represent strings:

String ::= OrdinaryString | HeredocString

Ordinary Strings

The following productions describe ordinary strings:

OrdinaryString ::= '<' (OrdinaryStringChar | EscapeSequence)* '>' OrdinaryStringChar ::= . \ ('\' | '<' | '>' | LineBreak)

Property: OrdinaryString → Value
The Value of an ordinary string is the concatenation of the Values from all its children.

The Value of an ordinary string char is its text.

Escape sequences are constructed as following:

EscapeSequence ::= '\' (EscapedCR | EscapedLF | EscapedTab | EscapedSpecialChar | CodePointRef | IgnoredWS) EscapedCR ::= 'r' EscapedLF ::= 'n' EscapedTab ::= 't' EscapedSpecialChar ::= [\<>{}] | '[' | ']' CodePointRef ::= 'u' Hex Hex Hex Hex Hex ::= [0-9A-F] IgnoredWS ::= LineBreak SingleLineWSChar*

The Values of the escape sequences EscapedCR, EscapedLF and EscapedTab are the unicode characters #x0D, #x0A and #x09. The Value of an EscapedSpecialChar is its text. The Value of a CodePointRef is the unicode character with the given hexadecimal codepoint. The Value of an IgnoredWS node is the empty string. The IgnoredWS escape sequence can be used to insert line breaks and indentations into strings without changing its Value.

Example: Ordinary Strings

<ordinary string\nthat cannot contain \ unescaped line breaks>

Its Value is the following:

ordinary string that cannot contain unescaped line breaks

Heredoc Strings

The following production describes heredoc strings:

HeredocString ::= '<' Delimiter '<' (AnyText | '\' Delimiter EscapeSequence)* '>' Delimiter '>'

Constraint: Syntactical Correctness
The text of all Delimiter children of a HeredocString MUST match and is called the Delimiter of the HeredocString. AnyText children MUST NOT contain > followed by Delimiter and then > or \ followed by Delimiter and then \.

Property: HeredocString → Value
The Value of an HeredocString is the concatenation of the Values from all children.

The Value of an AnyText node is its text.

Example: Heredoc Strings

<txt<heredoc string that can contain <, >, \txt\ txt or even <txt<.>txt>

Its Value is the following:

heredoc string that can contain <, >, txt or even <txt<.

Objects

Objects can compose other elements by using attributes. They have the following structure:

Object ::= '{' ObjType (Trivias PrefixDef)* (Trivias Attribute)* Trivias? '}' ObjType ::= (CastIndicator? (TypeName | '#' AliasName)) | InferenceIndicator CastIndicator ::= '=' InferenceIndicator ::= '~'

Constraint: Well-formedness
An AliasName child of an ObjType must be defined by a corresponding AliasDef element.

Definition: Cast Object
The parent Object of a CastIndicator node is called Cast Object.

Definition: Inference Object
The parent Object of a InferenceIndicator node is called Inference Object.

Property: Object → Qualified Type Name
Each Object that is not an Inference Object has a qualified type name. If the ObjType child has a TypeName child, its qualified type name is used. Otherwise, if the ObjType has an AliasName child, the qualified type name is used that is assigned to the alias name by the corresponding AliasDef element.

Example: Cast Object, Qualified Type Name

{!tyml 0.9 !ns/t:<tyml.org/example> !alias/#MyAliasName:<t/MyTypeName> } {=#MyAliasName <Value for implicit attribute>}

The root object of this document is a Cast Object and its qualified type name is tyml.org/example#MyTypeName.

Attributes are defined as follows:

Attribute ::= ImplicitAttribute | ExplicitAttribute ImplicitAttribute ::= AttributeValue TypeAttributeIndicator ::= "'" ExplicitAttribute ::= TypeAttributeIndicator? AttributeName ':' Trivias? AttributeValue

An AttributeName is defined similar to TypeName, however its prefix can be empty:

LocalAttrName ::= Identifier AttributeName ::= (Prefix '/')? LocalAttrName QualifiedAttrName ::= (Namespace | QualifiedTypeName) ':' LocalAttrName

An AttributeName consists of a prefix and a local attribute name: The prefix is the text of the Prefix child if it has one, otherwise it is Null. The local attribute name is the text of the LocalAttrName child.

Constraint: Well-formedness
An AttributeName MUST NOT resolve its prefix to Null unless the prefix is Null itself.

Property: AttributeName → Qualified Attribute Name
An AttributeName resolves to a QualifiedAttrName with a matching local attribute name.

Definition: Ordinary Attribute
If the prefix of an AttributeName is Null, its parent ExplicitAttribute is called Ordinary Attribute. In this case, the qualified type name of the parent Object is used as QualifiedTypeName child for the qualified attribute name.

Definition: Attached Attribute
Otherwise, if the prefix is not Null, its parent ExplicitAttribute is called Attached Attribute. In that case, the namespace the prefix is resolved to is used as Namespace child for the qualified attribute name.

Example: Attributes

{!tyml 0.9 !ns/:<tyml.org/example1> !ns/t:<tyml.org/example2>} {Root1 Attr1:0 /Attr2:0 t/Attr3:0} {t/Root2 Attr4:0 /Attr5:0 t/Attr6:0}

These attributes resolve to:

tyml.org/example1#Root1:Attr1, tyml.org/example1:Attr2, tyml.org/example2:Attr3, tyml.org/example2#Root2:Attr4, tyml.org/example1:Attr5, tyml.org/example2:Attr6,

Arrays

There are two different types of arrays: OrdinaryArrays and MarkupArrays:

Array ::= OrdinaryArray | MarkupArray

Ordinary arrays are specified as follows:

OrdinaryArray ::= '[' Expression? (Trivias Expression)* Trivias? ']'

The following production rules describe markup arrays:

MarkupArray ::= '![' Comment? (MarkupElement Comment?)* ']' MarkupElement ::= String | Object | OrdinaryArray | MarkupString MarkupStringChar ::= Char \ ([\<>{}] | '[' | ']') MarkupString ::= (MarkupStringChar | EscapeSequence)*

Hence, all whitespace characters within markup arrays are interpreted as markup strings.

Example: Array vs. Markup Array

![ This is an {Bold <Markup Array>}! ]

This represents the MarkupString and Object items This is an , {Bold ...} and ! . All whitespaces are treated as markup strings.

[ This is an {Bold <Array>}! ]

In contrast to the markup array, this represents the Primitive and Object items This, is, an, {Bold ...} and !. All separating whitespaces are treated as trivias.

Type System

Assignability

The set BaseTypeDefinitions represents unique types that cannot be assigned to each other unless explicitly stated. AliasTypeDefinitions represents types that stand for other types. These sets MUST be disjunct:

BaseTypeDefinitions∩AliasTypeDefinitions=∅\begin{aligned} \mathrm{BaseTypeDefinitions} \cap\mathrm{AliasTypeDefinitions} = \emptyset \end{aligned}​BaseTypeDefinitions∩AliasTypeDefinitions=∅​​

Together they form the set of all type definitions. Each type definition specfies an arity that defines how many type arguments it accepts:

TypeDefinitions:=BaseTypeDefinitions∪AliasTypeDefinitionsarity:TypeDefinitions→N0\begin{aligned} &\mathrm{TypeDefinitions} &&:=&&\mathrm{BaseTypeDefinitions} \cup\mathrm{AliasTypeDefinitions} \\ &\mathrm{arity}&&: &&\mathrm{TypeDefinitions} \to \mathbb{N}_0 \end{aligned}​​​​​TypeDefinitions​arity​​​​​​​:=​:​​​​​​​BaseTypeDefinitions∪AliasTypeDefinitions​TypeDefinitions→N​0​​​​

The term algebra Types represents all types that can be build using the given type definitions. A natural number n\begin{aligned}n\end{aligned}​n​​ represents a type variable. Both union (∪\begin{aligned}\cup\end{aligned}​∪​​) and instantiation ([...]\begin{aligned}[...]\end{aligned}​[...]​​) operations are interpreted as algebraic data type constructors. Types is the smallest set that contains all natural numbers and that is closed under type union and instantiation of type definitions:

N⊂Typest1,t2∈Types⇒t1∪t2∈Typest∈BaseTypeDefinitions,t1,...,tn∈Types⇒t[t1,...,tn]∈Typesifn=arity(t)\begin{aligned} \mathbb{N} &&\subset & \quad\mathrm{Types} \\ t_1, t_2 \in\mathrm{Types} &&\Rightarrow & \quad t_1 \cup t_2 \in\mathrm{Types} \\ t \in\mathrm{BaseTypeDefinitions}, t_1, ..., t_n \in\mathrm{Types} &&\Rightarrow &\quad t[t_1, ..., t_n] \in\mathrm{Types} \quad \text{if}\: n =\mathrm{arity}(t) \end{aligned}​N​t​1​​,t​2​​∈Types​t∈BaseTypeDefinitions,t​1​​,...,t​n​​∈Types​​​​​​​​⊂​⇒​⇒​​​Types​t​1​​∪t​2​​∈Types​t[t​1​​,...,t​n​​]∈Typesifn=arity(t)​​

BaseTypes are types which specify type arguments for BaseTypeDefinitions. ClosedTypes are types without any type variables.

BaseTypes:={t[t1,...,tn]∣t∈BaseTypeDefinitions,t1,...,tn∈Types,n=arity(t)}ClosedTypes:={t∈Types∣tdoes not contain any number}ClosedBaseTypes:=BaseTypes∩ClosedTypes\begin{aligned} \mathrm{BaseTypes} &&:=\quad& \{ t[t_1, ..., t_n] \; | \; t \in\mathrm{BaseTypeDefinitions}, t_1, ..., t_n \in\mathrm{Types}, n =\mathrm{arity}(t) \} \\ \mathrm{ClosedTypes} &&:=\quad& \{ t \in\mathrm{Types} \; | \; t \; \text{does not contain any number} \} \\ \mathrm{ClosedBaseTypes} &&:=\quad&\mathrm{BaseTypes} \cap\mathrm{ClosedTypes} \end{aligned}​BaseTypes​ClosedTypes​ClosedBaseTypes​​​​​​​​:=​:=​:=​​​{t[t​1​​,...,t​n​​]∣t∈BaseTypeDefinitions,t​1​​,...,t​n​​∈Types,n=arity(t)}​{t∈Types∣tdoes not contain any number}​BaseTypes∩ClosedTypes​​

In the following, Fin(S)\begin{aligned}{\mathrm{Fin}}(S)\end{aligned}​Fin(S)​​ denotes the set of all finite subsets from a set S\begin{aligned}S\end{aligned}​S​​.

The map directlyAssignableTo specifies a finite set of base types that instances of a given base type definition can be assigned to. The map aliasType specifies the type a given alias type definition refers to:

directlyAssignableTo:BaseTypeDefinitions→Fin(BaseTypes)aliasType:AliasTypeDefinitions→Types\begin{aligned} \mathrm{directlyAssignableTo}&&:& \quad\mathrm{BaseTypeDefinitions} \to {\mathrm{Fin}}(\mathrm{BaseTypes}) \\ \mathrm{aliasType}&&:& \quad\mathrm{AliasTypeDefinitions} \to\mathrm{Types} \end{aligned}​directlyAssignableTo​aliasType​​​​​​​:​:​​​BaseTypeDefinitions→Fin(BaseTypes)​AliasTypeDefinitions→Types​​

The return values of both maps MUST NOT contain numbers that are greater than the arity of their arguments.

The graph induced by directlyAssignableTo MUST NOT contain cycles. Type arguments are not considered and do not yield edges.

Insert replaces all occurrences of the number i\begin{aligned}i\end{aligned}​i​​ in its argument with the type ti\begin{aligned}t_i\end{aligned}​t​i​​​​:

insertt1,...,tn:Types→Types\begin{aligned} insert_{t_1, ..., t_n}:\mathrm{Types} \to\mathrm{Types} \end{aligned}​insert​t​1​​,...,t​n​​​​:Types→Types​​

normalize resolves aliases and factors out union types:

normalize:ClosedTypes→Fin(ClosedBaseTypes)t1∪t2↦normalize(t1)∪normalize(t2)t[t1,...,tn]↦normalize(insertt1,...,tn(aliased(t)))ift∈AliasTypeDefinitionst↦{t}ift∈BaseTypes\begin{aligned} \mathrm{normalize}:\mathrm{ClosedTypes} &&\to& \quad {\mathrm{Fin}}(\mathrm{ClosedBaseTypes}) \\ t_1 \cup t_2 &&\mapsto& \quad\mathrm{normalize}(t_1) \cup\mathrm{normalize}(t_2) \\ t[t_1, ..., t_n] &&\mapsto& \quad\mathrm{normalize}(\mathrm{insert}_{t_1, ..., t_n}(\mathrm{aliased}(t))) \quad \text{if}\;t \in\mathrm{AliasTypeDefinitions} \\ t &&\mapsto& \quad \{ t \} \quad \text{if}\: t \in\mathrm{BaseTypes} \end{aligned}​normalize:ClosedTypes​t​1​​∪t​2​​​t[t​1​​,...,t​n​​]​t​​​​​​​​​→​↦​↦​↦​​​Fin(ClosedBaseTypes)​normalize(t​1​​)∪normalize(t​2​​)​normalize(insert​t​1​​,...,t​n​​​​(aliased(t)))ift∈AliasTypeDefinitions​{t}ift∈BaseTypes​​

directlyAssignableTo can be continued on ClosedBaseTypes:

directlyAssignableTo:ClosedBaseTypes→Fin(ClosedBaseTypes)t[t1,...,tn]↦{insertt1,...,tn(t′)∣t′∈directlyAssignableTo(t)}\begin{aligned} \mathrm{directlyAssignableTo}: \quad\mathrm{ClosedBaseTypes} &&\to& \quad{\mathrm{Fin}}(\mathrm{ClosedBaseTypes}) \\ t[t_1, ..., t_n] &&\mapsto& \quad \{\mathrm{insert}_{t_1, ..., t_n}(t') \; | \; t' \in\mathrm{directlyAssignableTo}(t) \} \end{aligned}​directlyAssignableTo:ClosedBaseTypes​t[t​1​​,...,t​n​​]​​​​​​​→​↦​​​Fin(ClosedBaseTypes)​{insert​t​1​​,...,t​n​​​​(t​′​​)∣t​′​​∈directlyAssignableTo(t)}​​

This makes it possible to continue assignableTo as relation ⪯\begin{aligned}\preceq\end{aligned}​⪯​​ for ClosedTypes a\begin{aligned}a\end{aligned}​a​​ and b\begin{aligned}b\end{aligned}​b​​ (read "a\begin{aligned}a\end{aligned}​a​​ is assignable to b\begin{aligned}b\end{aligned}​b​​"):

a⪯b⇔∀a′[a1,...,an]∈normalize(a):∃b′[b1,...,bn]∈normalize(b):(a′=b′∧∀i∈{1,...,n}:ai⪯bi∧bi⪯ai)∨∃t∈directlyAssignableTo(a′[a1,...,an]):t⪯b[b1,...,bn]\begin{aligned} a \preceq b \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad &\forall a'[a_1, ..., a_n] \in\mathrm{normalize}(a): \exists b'[b_1, ..., b_n] \in\mathrm{normalize}(b):\\ &(a' = b' \:\land\: \forall i \in \{1, ..., n\}: a_i \preceq b_i \:\land\: b_i \preceq a_i) \\ \lor \: &\exists t \in\mathrm{directlyAssignableTo}(a'[a_1, ..., a_n]): t \preceq b[b_1, ..., b_n] \end{aligned}​a⪯b⇔​​∨​​​∀a​′​​[a​1​​,...,a​n​​]∈normalize(a):∃b​′​​[b​1​​,...,b​n​​]∈normalize(b):​(a​′​​=b​′​​∧∀i∈{1,...,n}:a​i​​⪯b​i​​∧b​i​​⪯a​i​​)​∃t∈directlyAssignableTo(a​′​​[a​1​​,...,a​n​​]):t⪯b[b​1​​,...,b​n​​]​​

Types in Tyml

Definition: Root Types
The set BaseTypeDefinitions contains at least the root types Any, Primitive, String and Object with an arity of zero and Array with an arity of one. All these types are directly assignable only to the root type Any and Any is not directly assignable to any type.

User defined type definitions expand the TypeDefinitions set. Each user defined type definition can be adressed by an unique name that matches the QualifiedTypeName production. Except alias type definitions, user defined type definitions are members of the set BaseTypeDefinitions and can extend other BaseTypes. Such type definitions are at least directly assignable to the type they extend. User defined type definitions belong to exactly one of the following categories:

  • Primitive Type Definitions

    Extend either a primitive type or the root type Primitive. Have an arity of zero.

  • String Types Definitions

    Extend either a string type or the root type String. Have an arity of zero.

  • Object Types Definitions

    Extend either an object type or the root type Object. Their arity is user defined. Object types specify a list of interface types they implement. They are directly assignable to the type they extend and to all interfaces they implement.

  • Interface Types Definitions

    Specify a list of closed interface types they extend. Their arity is user defined. They are directly assignable to Object and all interfaces they extend.

  • Array Types Definitions

    Extends an other array type or the root type Array. Has an arity of one.

  • Alias Types

    Defines an alias for a type. Its arity is user defined.

Object Types

Object types define a list of own attributes.

Attributes have the following properties:

  • Name. The attribute's name. Its values must match the Identifier production.
  • Type. The attribute's type. Its values are members of Types. Must not contain numbers that are greater than the object type's arity.
  • CanBeImplicit. Is either true or false and specfies whether the name of the attribute can be omitted.
  • IsOptional. Is either true or false and specfies whether the attribute is optional.

Property: Object Type → Attribute Liste
The attribute list of a given object type is defined as the concatenation of the extended type's attribute list with the list of own attributes.

Elements of the attribute list MUST have different names.

Property: Object Type → nth Implicit Attribute
The n\begin{aligned}n\end{aligned}​n​​th implicit attribute of an object type refers to the n\begin{aligned}n\end{aligned}​n​​th element of the attribute list whose CanBeImplicit property is set to true.

All these definitions apply to closed object types likewise. However, numbers within the type property of attributes are replaced by the corresponding type argument.

Defining User Defined Types

User defined types are described by tyml.org/typedef/0.9#DefinitionPackage objects.

Type Inference

The type of an expression depends on the expression kind, its value and its expected type:

inferTypeexpected∈Types:Expressions→Types∪{null}\begin{aligned} inferType_{\mathrm{expected} \in\mathrm{Types}}:\mathrm{Expressions} \to\mathrm{Types} \cup \{\mathrm{null} \} \end{aligned}​inferType​expected∈Types​​:Expressions→Types∪{null}​​

Let {e1,e2,...,en}\begin{aligned}\{ e_1, e_2, ..., e_n \}\end{aligned}​{e​1​​,e​2​​,...,e​n​​}​​ be the result of normalize(expected)\begin{aligned}\mathrm{normalize}(\mathrm{expected})\end{aligned}​normalize(expected)​​.

  • If the expression is a Primitive (or a String): If there is exactly one ei\begin{aligned}e_i\end{aligned}​e​i​​​​ that is assignable to the root type Primitive (or String) whose constraints are met by the value of the expression, the inferred type is ei\begin{aligned}e_i\end{aligned}​e​i​​​​. If there is no such an ei\begin{aligned}e_i\end{aligned}​e​i​​​​ at all, but an ej\begin{aligned}e_j\end{aligned}​e​j​​​​ that equals the root type Any, the inferred type is the closed root type Primitive (or String). Otherwise, the inferred type is Null.

  • If the expression is an Array: If there is exactly one ei\begin{aligned}e_i\end{aligned}​e​i​​​​ that is assignable to the root type Array, the inferred type is ei\begin{aligned}e_i\end{aligned}​e​i​​​​. If there is no such an ei\begin{aligned}e_i\end{aligned}​e​i​​​​ at all, but an ej\begin{aligned}e_j\end{aligned}​e​j​​​​ that equals the root type Any, the inferred type is the root type Array instantiated with the root type Any. Otherwise, the inferred type is Null.

  • If the expression is an Object:

    If the object is an Inference Object: If there is exactly one ei\begin{aligned}e_i\end{aligned}​e​i​​​​ that is an user defined object type, the inferred type is ei\begin{aligned}e_i\end{aligned}​e​i​​​​. Otherwise, the inferred type is Null.

    If the object is not an Inference Object:

    The qualified type name of the Object must point to a user defined type. If the object has an attached attribute with the qualified attribute name tyml.org/types:TypeArgs, the types blablablab. Otherwise, the type arguments are inferred from the expected type.

Constraint: Validness
If an Object is not a Cast Object, its estimated type MUST be an object type.

Validation

The expected type of the root object is the root type Any.

Defining Types
